Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Expectation2: Leading the daily prayers in the mosque
Situation2: The regular backup is away, so most congregants expect him to step forward for the scheduled prayer.
Story: I was just finishing up the highlights on a first-time client when I noticed her frown in the mirror. She hesitated, then quietly said the colour was too brassy, not what she’d hoped for. My heart sank—I knew how important it was to make a good impression, and I wanted her to leave happy. I was about to reassure her and offer to fix it when my phone buzzed. A message from the mosque committee flashed on the screen: “Backup is sick. Can you lead the prayer in ten minutes?” I glanced at the clock. The prayer was about to start, and the mosque was only a few blocks away, but I couldn’t leave my client mid-appointment, especially when she was upset. Yet, as the imam, the community counted on me, especially today. My mind raced, torn between my duty to my client and my responsibility to the congregation, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
